text: Ron Ritchhart, in his book Intellectual Character, as well as his work with Visible Thinking throughÂ Harvardâ€™s Project Zero, describes the forces that comprise a â€˜culture of thinkingâ€˜ in the classroom. Hereâ€™s my takeâ€¦ 1. Model thinking. Talk about your own thinking. Make your thinking explicit. Share ideas. Wonder aloud. Explore possibilities with your students. Acknowledge that you donâ€™t have all the answers. 2. Allow thinking time. Donâ€™t expect answers as soon as you have asked a question. Donâ€™t repeat or rephrase the question if there isnâ€™t an immediate response. Get used to the silence. Give students time to formulate their thinking. Donâ€™t call on the first kids to have their hands up. Sometimes, get every student to write their thoughts down before you call on anyone. Give time to discuss their thoughts with a partner or group before sharing with the class.  3.Â Provide Â opportunities for thinking. Pose problems. Encourage exploration and inquiry. Set meaningful, real-life problems. Encourage students to take and defend a position, make predictions, support their ideas with evidence, articulate and test theories, make connections with prior knowledge.  4.Â Create a physical environment conducive to thinking. Donâ€™t have seats facing the front. Arrange the seats in groups so that kids can collaborate and construct meaning together. Allow movement for interacting with different people. Display student thinking on the walls. Put up a series of sticky notes showing development of thinking over a unit.  5.Â Introduce thinking routines. In the same way that classes have routines for management and organization, students get used to thinking when it becomes routine. Routines need to be short, clear and easy to remember and repeated often. Â Thinking routines provide a scaffold and structure for thinking. They give students guidelines within which to think and a direction to head towards in their thinking.  6.Â Show that you value thinking. Name and notice thinking. Avoid praise for individual thinking. Acknowledge every contribution. Make it clear that all thinking is acceptable. Respond respectfully to all students. Ask for clarification and development of ideas. Encourage students to build on each othersâ€™ thinking.  7.Â Give them something worth thinking about! Make sure your stimulus is always something worth thinking about. Create tension and cognitive disonance. Create strong provocations that will invite students into the topic. Ask powerful questions. Think laterally, it isnâ€™t always something obvious. Use art. Use music. Use artifacts.  8.Â Let go. A thinking culture works best when the teacher isnâ€™t in charge. Â Sit at the back sometimes, donâ€™t always stand in front. Donâ€™t paraphrase studentâ€™s thinking into what you think they mean. Every response does not have to go through the teacher. Donâ€™t be the filter.  9. Focus on big ideas. Donâ€™t teach only facts and content. Â Look at big ideas, rather than just topics. Â Explore events and ideas through one or more conceptual lenses for deeper learning. Â Facts are locked in time, place or situation, while concepts are transferable. Encourage transfer of learning to other contexts. 10. Focus on learning, not work Make sure you and your students know the reason for every learning experience. Donâ€™t give â€˜busy workâ€™. #8 has to be done in order for any of this to really work. As teachers, we often struggle letting go of the power and letting students choose/guide their own learning. If we want students to problem solve and think critically, we have to let go and allow them to. Too often we worry about meeting this standard or learning that piece of content, that we try to control the (learning) process to ensure that, when in reality we are simply limiting potential and possibilities.Students need to feel â€œsafeâ€ enough to think in your class. Another great list, Ed! I would add: â€“ Encourage alternative ideasMany times a response that reflects an alternative way of thinking is ridiculed by the other students. Encourage different ways of looking at ideas and help those who think differently to be comfortable in expressing their ideas. Create an environment where even the most outrageously alternative ideas can be safely expressed.

I completely agree.  My goal each year is for the students to truly think about possibilities and not just try to remember what I have told them.  I definitely want them to pay attention to what I say, but I really want them to always be considering, questioning, and evaluating- even my answers.  Often responses that are alternative to what is expected can cause an â€œahaâ€ moment because they illuminate an aspect we may not have considered.  So, hopefully students can see that divergent thinking and more linear thinking are BOTH part of higher order problem solving and critical thinking.  I want kids to grow in their abilities to think for themselves and question.  It seems to me that if I set the stage for this from the beginning, then it becomes a safe environment for sharing alternate perspectivesâ€¦all input is viewed as a contribution to the process.  Iâ€™m not the most linear thinker myself and (unfortunately) that can leave a less than organized comment! Anyway, I appreciated the thoughts.
